724014f-a.title: Manhattan: Washington Square North - University Place
724014f-a.text:
Washington SQuare North, from University Place to Macdougal Street, seen across the N.E. corner of the park. The Washington Arch is
shown at the loft.
April 1925.
Brown Brothers.
724014f-a.folder: Washington Square North & University Place, Manhattan, NY

724016f-a.title: Manhattan: Washington Square North - University Place
724016f-a.text: Washington Sduare North, west from (No. 8, right) a point to the west of University Place. On the right are fine old private residences that face onto Wdashington Square. At tho left and in said park is the famous hashington Arch, heading as it does, Fifth Avenue. This thoroughfare appears in the center of this view. The buildings this side of same are in the Spring of 1u39 to be reconstructed for apartment use. This is in variance to their past history as the Sailors Snug Harbor Corpotation their owner has made a feature of their residential aspects. Across the Avenue at the N. W. corner is the former Rhinelander home which has gone thru this process, retaining its external appearance.
724016f-a.folder: Washington Square North & University Place, Manhattan, NY

724000f-a.title: Manhattan: Washington Square North - University Place
724000f-a.text:
1-13 Washington Square North, from University Place to Fifth Avewue, seea across the N.E. corner of the park. The view on University Place is north along the west sise, up to Union Square. These old houses, except No. 3, the building with the fire escapes,
are old residences antedatiwg the Civil War.
In the right background may be seen the Metropolitan Life Iwsurance
tower at Masison Aveaue and 24th Street.
Around 1926.
Ewing Galloway.  Nie W 5S3
724000f-a.folder: Washington Square North & University Place, Manhattan, NY

724022f-b.title: Manhattan: Washington Square - University Place
724022f-b.text:
Washington Square Park, central and southwestern cuarter, seen from 1 University Place. Children may be seen bathing in the center
fountain.
The old Hotel Holley, 35-6 Washington Scuare West, is sandwiched in between two new buildings erected around 1930. On the S.W. corner of 4th and Macdougal Streets may be seen the Washington View apartments, erected in the late 1880's. The Judson Hemorial Baptist Church on the S.W. corner of Thompson Street is not quite all in the picture. The tower adjoining it is part of the same building; it was formerly the Judson Hotel, but is
now a New York University dormitory.
On the honizon may be seen the North River and the Palisades.
July 17, 1935.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, not showing the Holley Chambers at 33 Washington Square West, but including the entire Judson Memorial Church.
July 17, 1935.
P. L. Sperr.
724022f-b.folder: Washington Square & University Place, Manhattan, NY

724022f-a.folder: Washington Square & University Place, Manhattan, NY

724023f-b.title: Manhattan: Washington Square - University Place
724023f-b.text:
Washington Square Park, the northwestern corner, seen from 71 Washington Square South. In the foreground is the fountain, used as a children's swimming pool, and Washington Arch. In the background may be seen the old Jefferson Market clock tower
at Sixth Avenue and 10th Street.
Between the new apartment building (circa 1928) at 30 Washington Square West and the Richmond Hill (circa 1900) may be seen the Earle Hotel at 103 Waverly Place, adjoining the N.W. corner, which is occupied by the Earle Annex. This is one of the
Knott hotels, built around 1905.
July, 1935.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, but not showing the corners of Washington Square North
and Fifth Avenue.
July, 1935.
P. L. Sperr.
(3)
A similar view as seen from No. 1 University Place.
724023f-b.folder: Washington Square & University Place, Manhattan, NY

724026f-a.title: Manhattan: Washington Square Park - [Washington Square (North).]
724026f-a.text:
Washington Scquare Park, northwestern qquarter, not including the corner,
seen from the southwest.
11-14 Washington Suuare North, and No. 13 on the N.E. corner of Fifth Avenue, are shown, and behind them the tall apartment hotel One
Fifth Avenue.
August, 1935.
P. L. Sperr.
724026f-a.folder: Washington Square Park & [Washington Square (North).], Manhattan, NY

724003f-a.title: Manhattan: Washington Square North - University Place
724003f-a.text:
7-8 Washington Square North, between University Place and Fifth Ave;
No. 7 is on the right.
About 1935.
R. w. Hill.
724003f-a.folder: Washington Square North & University Place, Manhattan, NY

723999f-a.title: Manhattan: Washington Square North - University Place
723999f-a.text:
1-13 Washington Square North, (right to left) north side, from University Place to Fifth Avenue as seen from the roof of 71 Washington Square South, across the Park, with the northeast corner of Fifth Avenue in the foreground and the midtown skyscrapers in the background. The Empire State Building (1930) rises behind 55 Fifth Avenue, to the center of the picture. To the right of same appears the Metropolitan tower (1907) and the New York lLife Bldg.(1926) and the Chrysler Bldg. (1930) at 42nd Street. Partially shown in a decapitated form in the foreground, is No. 1 Fifth Avenue, a modern Apartment house.
July 1935.
Views 1 and 2
P. L. Sperr.
No. 3.
An eastward view of the same row of buildings as photographed from Fifth Avenue. In the background,at the S.E. and N.E. corners respectively of Waverly Place,apnears the law department of New York
University and a new Apartment house.
723999f-a.folder: Washington Square North & University Place, Manhattan, NY

724002f-a.text:
6 Washington Square North, north side, between University Place and Fifth Avenue, showing the lower portion and entrance to one of the row of old New York residences. These are the Sailors
Snug Harbor holdinga.
1939
Gift of Beecher Ogden

724001f-b.title: Manhattan: Washington Square North - University Place
724001f-b.text:
(1)
3-13 Washington Square North, north side, from but not including University Place to but not including Fifth Ave., with the new No. One Fifth Ave. apartment hotel rising in the background. The view is across the Square from the S.E. corner.
December 28, 1927.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, showing more of the S.E. side of Washington Square Park.
February 23, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.  RNe w 5tS
(3)
The same, two years later, as seen from the S.E. corner of
Washington Square.
The Empire State Building, in the far background, has been erected
since the date of the previous view.
July. 1935.
P. L. Sperr.

724015f-b.title: Manhattan: Washington Square North - University Place
724015f-b.text:
(1)
Washington Square North, west from University Place, showing various private dwellings (erected about 1830) that face Washington Square. The block front in the foreground are holdings of the Sailors Smug Barbor. Fifth Avenue is in the center and the Rhinelander stands at the far corner. View 2 is similar,
from a point closer to Fifth Avenue.
P. L. Sperr  View 1: April 26, 1933
NO REPRODUCTIONS  View 2: August 25, 1933
(2)
Washington Square North, looking towards Fifth Avenue from University Place. Former residential section of New York's
Four Hundred.
P. L. Sperr  May 11, 1940
(3)
Washington Square North, looking towards Fifth Avenue from University Place. Former residential section of New York's
F3ur Hundred.
L. Sperr  May 11, 1940

724017f-a.text:

1 to 6 Washington Square North, at and adjoining the N.W. corner of University Place. Compare this with later pictures of this
block.
September 8, 1905.
Brown Brothers.
(2)
to 5 Washington Square North, the same houses, nearly thirty years later, seen across the N.E. corner of Washington Scuare from Washington SGuare East and Washington Place. The view at the right ia north on Washington Sduare East and University Plsce. New york lniversity students and others may be seen along the sidewalk on either side of Washington Square.
February 23, 1933.
P. L. Spenr.
